title: 113_hr1582
content: The Energy Consumers Relief Act of 2013 prohibits the Environmental Protection Agency from finalizing energy-related rules costing over $1 billion if they will have significant adverse effects on the economy. The Secretary of Energy must determine the rule's impact before it can be promulgated. Before finalizing any energy-related rule costing over $1 billion, the EPA must report to Congress with details including the rule, costs, and benefits. The EPA must report to Congress before finalizing any energy-related rule costing over $1 billion, including a copy of the rule, a concise statement, cost estimates, and benefit estimates with associated modeling and limitations. The EPA must report to Congress before finalizing any energy-related rule costing over $1 billion, including a copy of the rule, cost and benefit estimates, modeling details, assumptions, limitations, and certification of data preservation for public review on the Agency's website. The EPA must provide Congress with a report before implementing any energy-related rule costing over $1 billion. This report includes cost and benefit estimates, modeling details, and a certification of data preservation for public review on the Agency's website. Additionally, it must include an estimate of the increases in energy prices. The report to Congress for energy-related rules costing over $1 billion must include cost and benefit estimates, modeling details, data preservation certification for public review, potential energy price increases, and employment effects. The report to Congress for energy-related rules costing over $1 billion must include cost and benefit estimates, modeling details, data preservation certification for public review, potential energy price increases, and employment effects. The Secretary of Energy, in consultation with relevant agencies, will prepare an independent analysis on potential impacts, including job losses and shifts in employment, resulting from the rule's implementation or enforcement. The Secretary of Energy, in consultation with relevant agencies, will conduct an independent analysis to determine if the rule will cause energy price increases for consumers, impact fuel diversity, and result in job losses or shifts in employment. The Secretary of Energy, in consultation with relevant agencies, will conduct an independent analysis to determine the impact of the rule on energy prices, fuel diversity, and energy supply, distribution, and use. The Secretary of Energy will analyze the rule's impact on energy prices, fuel diversity, and energy supply, distribution, and use, considering adverse effects on the economy. The Secretary of Energy will analyze the rule's impact on energy prices, fuel diversity, and energy supply, distribution, or use, including any adverse effects on the economy. If adverse effects are determined, consultation with other relevant agencies will be conducted. The Secretary, in consultation with relevant agencies, will determine if a rule will have significant adverse effects on the economy by considering costs, benefits, and uncertainties in calculations. The Secretary, in consultation with relevant agencies, will determine if a rule will have significant adverse effects on the economy by considering costs, benefits, uncertainties, and impacts on economic indicators. The Secretary will determine the economic impacts of a rule, including costs, benefits, uncertainties, and effects on economic indicators, and publish the results in the Federal Register. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the terms "direct costs" and "indirect costs" are defined according to the Environmental Protection Agency's guidelines. The term "energy-related rule that is estimated to cost more than $1 billion" refers to EPA rules regulating energy production, supply, distribution, or use. The term "rule" in this Act refers to regulations by the Environmental Protection Agency or other governmental entities that impose direct and indirect costs exceeding $1 billion. PROHIBITION ON USE OF SOCIAL COST OF CARBON IN ANALYSIS. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency is prohibited from using the social cost of carbon in cost-benefit analysis for energy-related rules costing over $1 billion, unless authorized by Federal law. The term "social cost of carbon" refers to the cost described in a technical support document. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency is prohibited from using the social cost of carbon in cost-benefit analysis for energy-related rules costing over $1 billion, unless authorized by Federal law. The term "social cost of carbon" refers to the cost described in a technical support document published by the Interagency Working Group on Social Cost of Carbon in May 2013. The House of Representatives passed a bill related to monetized damages from increased carbon dioxide emissions on August 1, 2013. Signed by Karen L. Haas, Clerk.
